dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, Host_B, big news from across the pond this week, huh?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Host B, big news from across the pond this week, huh?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely, Host_A. The never-ending Brexit saga, it, uh, it continues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely, Host A. The never-ending Brexit saga, it, uh, it continues.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? So, the EU leaders, they've actually agreed to grant the UK a three-month delay to Brexit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? So, the E U leaders, they've actually agreed to grant the U K a three-month delay to Brexit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: EU leaders have agreed to grant the U.K. a three-month delay to Brexit

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's right. So, the October 31st deadline, uh, that's now extended until January 31st, 2020, at the latest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's right. So, the October thirty first deadline, uh, that's now extended until January thirty first, twenty twenty, at the latest.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the October 31 exit deadline has been extended until January 31, 2020, at the latest.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And Donald Tusk, the EU Council president, he actually confirmed this on Twitter, calling it a "flextension." Which, you know, sounds kinda cool.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Donald Tusk, the E U Council president, he actually confirmed this on Twitter, calling it a flextension. Which, you know, sounds kinda cool.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: EU Council president Donald Tusk tweeted the confirmation on Monday. He said: The EU27 has agreed that it will accept the U.K.s request for a Brexit flextension until 31 January 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] A flextension! I love that term. But it basically means the UK can't leave before January 31st, unless, like, both parliaments actually ratify a deal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A flextension! I love that term. But it basically means the U K can't leave before January thirty first, unless, like, both parliaments actually ratify a deal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The flextension means that the U.K. would be allowed to leave the EU before January 31, if the British and European Parliaments ratifiy a deal before then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, uh, quite the caveat. Especially given Boris Johnson, who, you know, famously said he'd rather be "dead in a ditch" than further delay Brexit. And now he's the one sending the letter requesting it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, uh, quite the caveat. Especially given Boris Johnson, who, you know, famously said he'd rather be dead in a ditch than further delay Brexit. And now he's the one sending the letter requesting it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson has previously said he would rather be dead in a ditch than to further delay... It comes after British Prime Minister Boris Johnson was forced to send a letter to the EU requesting an extension

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, well, he was, um, legally mandated to send that letter, even after his Brexit bill kind of got approved by UK parliamentarians. It's a bit of a tricky situation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, well, he was, um, legally mandated to send that letter, even after his Brexit bill kind of got approved by U K parliamentarians. It's a bit of a tricky situation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson was forced by law to ask the EU for an extension earlier this month, after he failed to get his Brexit deal approved by U.K. parliamentarians... Last week, lawmakers approved Johnsons deal in principle, by voting to approve Johnsons Withdrawal Agreement Bill

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And this whole delay, it means Johnson's now trying to actively avoid a general election this December. Lawmakers are debating that as we speak, I think.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And this whole delay, it means Johnson's now trying to actively avoid a general election this December. Lawmakers are debating that as we speak, I think.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The move now means Johnson will push for a general election this December, with British lawmakers set to debate the move this afternoon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is a complete turnaround, right? He really wanted to leave on October 31st, no matter what. And now, uh, that's definitely not happening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is a complete turnaround, right? He really wanted to leave on October thirty first, no matter what. And now, uh, that's definitely not happening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson has repeatedly said that he wanted the U.K. to leave the EU on October 31 do or die, but that certainly will not happen now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Nope. And let's not forget, just last week, lawmakers actually rejected his deal in principle. They, uh, they failed to approve his Withdrawal Agreement Bill.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Nope. And let's not forget, just last week, lawmakers actually rejected his deal in principle. They, uh, they failed to approve his Withdrawal Agreement Bill.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last week, lawmakers approved Johnsons deal in principle, by voting to approve Johnsons Withdrawal Agreement Bill, which sets out the terms of the U.K.s exit from the EU.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah! And then he paused the deal after they wanted, like, more time to debate it, which, you know, is fair enough.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah! And then he paused the deal after they wanted, like, more time to debate it, which, you know, is fair enough.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson then paused the deal after lawmakers rejected a short three-day window in which to debate it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But now he's saying he'll, um, allow lawmakers to ignore that deal if they agree to blocking an election on December 12th. It's like, a whole new layer of complexity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But now he's saying he'll, um, allow lawmakers to ignore that deal if they agree to blocking an election on December twelfth. It's like, a whole new layer of complexity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for the bill to progress further, Johnson said on Friday that he would allow lawmakers to debate it if they agreed to allowing an election on December 12.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's just a constant back and forth, isn't it? Like, what even is the plan anymore? It's all so fluid.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just a constant back and forth, isn't it? Like, what even is the plan anymore? It's all so fluid.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. So, the Brexit rollercoaster, it just keeps on rolling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. So, the Brexit rollercoaster, it just keeps on rolling.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Indeed. We'll be keeping an eye on it for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Indeed. We'll be keeping an eye on it for sure.
